If you think of a _sprite_ as a collection of values that represents an object in the real world, then the _properties_ of a sprite are like variables that hold all of those values. Some of the most common sprite properties include:

![](https://cdo-curriculum.s3.amazonaws.com/media/uploads/sprite.x.png)

![](https://cdo-curriculum.s3.amazonaws.com/media/uploads/sprite.y.png)

![](https://cdo-curriculum.s3.amazonaws.com/media/uploads/sprite.rotation.png)

![](https://cdo-curriculum.s3.amazonaws.com/media/uploads/sprite.scale.png)

![](https://cdo-curriculum.s3.amazonaws.com/media/uploads/sprite.visible.png)

## Dot Notation

Notice that all of the examples above follow a common pattern of **sprite label . sprite property**. We call this format _dot notation_. The first part will _always_ be unique to the sprite that you want to modify, and the second part will _always_ be one of the properties common to all sprites.

## Reading and Writing Properties

Sprite properties, like variables, are values that sometimes we want to just read, and sometimes that we want to write to. When you drag out a sprite property it will take out a different form depending on whether you are _reading_ its value, or _writing_ it.

![](https://cdo-curriculum.s3.amazonaws.com/media/uploads/property-assignment.png)

In the first image above the [`sprite.x`(#f78183)](/docs/gamelab/x/) block is being dragged into a place where it is being read, so it keeps it's normal form.

In the second image, the [`sprite.y`(#f78183)](/docs/gamelab/y/) block is being dragged onto a new line where it will be written to, so it's changed into the form `sprite.y = ___`.
